docs.title: LTB K8s Backend Documentation
docs.text: The LTB K8s Backend manages LTB Lab Template Deployments and User management.

docs.title: Naming
docs.text: The following naming conventions are used in the project:

docs.title: Naming conventions in Go
docs.text:
• camelCase for variables and functions
  • PascalCase for types and functions that need to be exported

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
• labStatus: variable name for a status of a lab instance
  • GetLabStatus: name for an exported function

docs.title: Coding
docs.text: • The Go extension in VSCode has a linting capability, so that will be used for linting.

docs.title: Lab Topology Builder (LTB)
docs.text: LTB is a tool that allows you to build a topology of virtual machines and containers, which are connected to each other according to the network topology you have defined.

docs.title: LTB Kubernetes Operator
docs.text: LTB Kubernetes Operator is a custom Kubernetes controller that allows you to deploy and manage applications and their components on Kubernetes using custom resources.

docs.title: Custom Resource (CR)
docs.text: Custom Resource is an extension of LTB Kubernetes API that allows you to create your own objects and store them in the Kubernetes cluster. In LTB, CR is the YAML file that is provided by the user.

docs.title: Custom Resource Definition (CRD)
docs.text: Custom Resource Definition (CRD) is a Kubernetes API that allows you to define your own custom resources.

docs.title: Kubernetes Cluster
docs.text: Kubernetes Cluster is a set of nodes that run containerized applications managed by Kubernetes.

docs.title: Lab Template
docs.text: Lab Template is a YAML file that defines the topology of the lab. It contains information about the devices that are part of the lab, as well as the network topology.

docs.title: Device
docs.text: A device is either a KubeVirt VM or a container. It has a device type, a device version, and a device name.

docs.title: Lab
docs.text: Lab is a YAML file (CR) that defines a lab instance. It holds the details from the lab template, and some additional information, such as the lab name. It also has a status field that is updated by the Kubernetes operator.

docs.title: Lab Instance (Lab) (LTB)
docs.text: Lab Instance is a deployment of the lab template. It is deployed by the Kubernetes Operator in the Kubernetes cluster.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
WSL version 0.67.6 and higher

Active Ubuntu WSL needed: 

sudo vim /etc/wsl.conf

# /etc/wsl.conf
[boot]
systemd=true
Restart WSL with wsl.exe --shutdown and opening the WSL again.

docs.title: Option 1: K3S install
docs.text:
sudo mkdir -p /etc/rancher/k3s/
sudo vim /etc/rancher/k3s/config.yaml
write-kubeconfig-mode: "0644"

curl -sfL https://get.k3s.io | INSTALL_K3S_VERSION="v1.26.1+k3s1" sudo -E sh -

docs.title: Option 2: K3D install
docs.text:
Prerequisites: Docker Desktop installed and running or Docker installed in WSL 

curl -s https://raw.githubusercontent.com/k3d-io/k3d/main/install.sh | TAG=v5.4.7 bash

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• curl
  • gpg version 2.0+

docs.title: 1. Download the release binary
docs.text:
Set platform information: 

export ARCH=$(case $(uname -m) in x86_64) echo -n amd64 ;; aarch64) echo -n arm64 ;; *) echo -n $(uname -m) ;; esac)
export OS=$(uname | awk '{print tolower($0)}')

Download the binary for your platform:

export OPERATOR_SDK_Version=1.26.1
export OPERATOR_SDK_DL_URL=https://github.com/operator-framework/operator-sdk/releases/download/${OPERATOR_SDK_Version}
curl -LO ${OPERATOR_SDK_DL_URL}/operator-sdk_${OS}_${ARCH}

docs.title: 2. Verify the downloaded binary (Optional)
docs.text:
Import the operator-sdk release GPG key from keyserver.ubuntu.com:

gpg --keyserver keyserver.ubuntu.com --recv-keys 052996E2A20B5C7E

Download the checksums file and its signature, then verify the signature (optional):

curl -LO ${OPERATOR_SDK_DL_URL}/checksums.txt
curl -LO ${OPERATOR_SDK_DL_URL}/checksums.txt.asc
gpg -u "Operator SDK (release) <cncf-operator-sdk@cncf.io>" --verify checksums.txt.asc

You should see something similar to the following:

gpg: assuming signed data in 'checksums.txt'
gpg: Signature made Fri 30 Oct 2020 12:15:15 PM PDT
gpg:                using RSA key ADE83605E945FA5A1BD8639C59E5B47624962185
gpg: Good signature from "Operator SDK (release) <cncf-operator-sdk@cncf.io>" [ultimate]

Make sure the checksums match:

grep operator-sdk_${OS}_${ARCH} checksums.txt | sha256sum -c -

You should see something similar to the following:

operator-sdk_linux_amd64: OK

docs.title: 3. Install the release binary in your PATH
docs.text:
chmod +x operator-sdk_${OS}_${ARCH} && sudo mv operator-sdk_${OS}_${ARCH} /usr/local/bin/
Verify the installation:

operator-sdk version

docs.title: Install Go
docs.text:
Step 1 - Downloading Go lang binary files Visit official downloads page and grab file using either wget command or curl command: 

# let us download a file with curl on Linux command line #
GO_VERSION="1.20.1" # go version
ARCH="amd64" # go archicture
wget -L "https://golang.org/dl/go${GO_VERSION}.linux-${ARCH}.tar.gz"
rm -rf /usr/local/go && tar -C /usr/local -xzf go1.20.1.linux-amd64.tar.gz

Step 2 - Add to PATH 

echo 'export PATH="$PATH:/usr/local/go/bin"' >> ~/.bashrc
source ~/.bashrc

Step 3 - Verify that you've installed Go by opening a command prompt and typing the following command: 

go version

docs.title: Kubernetes Lab Topology Builder Architecture
docs.text: The Kubernetes Lab Topology Builder (K8s-LTB) is a Kubernetes native version of the Lab Topology Builder (LTB). It is composed of a Frontend and a Backend.

docs.title: Frontend
docs.text:
The frontend is responsible for the following tasks:

  • Providing a web UI for the user to interact with the labs.
  • Providing a web UI for the admin to manage:
  • users
  • lab templates
  • lab deployments
  • reservations

docs.title: Backend
docs.text:
The backend is composed of the following components:

  • API
  • Operator

The backend is responsible for the following tasks:

  • parsing the yaml topology files
  • deploying/destroying the containers and vms
  • exposes status of lab deployments
  • exposes information on how to access the deployed containers and vms
  • provides remote ssh capabilities
  • provides remote Wireshark capture capabilities
  • managing reservations (create, delete, etc.)
  • exposes node resource usage
  • user management
  • exposes information about a device (version, groups, etc.)

docs.title: Current (KVM/Docker)-base LTB Architecture
docs.text:
Currently the KVM/Docker based LTB is composed of the following containers:

  • Frontend built with React
  • Backend built with Django
  • Deployment built with docker-compose

docs.title: Backend
docs.text:
The backend is accessible via API and a Admin Web UI. It is responsible for the following tasks:

  • parsing the yaml topology files
  • deploying/destroying the containers and vms
  • exposes status of lab deployments
  • exposes information on how to access the deployed containers and vms
  • provides remote ssh capabilities
  • provides remote Wireshark capture capabilities
  • managing reservations (create, delete, etc.)
  • exposes node resource usage
  • user management
  • exposes information about a device (version, groups, etc.)

It is composed of the following components:

  • Reservations
  • Running lab store
  • Template store
  • Authentication

The orchestration component is responsible for creating different tasks using Celery and executing them on a remote host. There are 4 different types of tasks:

  • DeploymentTask
  • Deploys containers in docker
  • Deploys VMs using KVM
  • Creates connections between containers and VMs using an OVS bridge
  • RemovalTask
  • Removes a running lab
  • MirrorInterfaceTask
  • Creates a mirror interface on a connection
  • SnapshotTask
  • Takes a snapshot of a running lab

docs.title: Reservations
docs.text:
The reservation component is responsible for reserving system resources in advance. It is responsible for the following tasks:

  • Create a reservation
  • Delete a reservation
  • Update a reservation

docs.title: Running lab store
docs.text:
This component is responsible for storing information about running labs, such as:

  • The devices taking part in the running lab, inclusive of the interfaces
  • Connection information

docs.title: Template store
docs.text: This component is responsible for storing lab templates.

docs.title: Authentication
docs.text: This component is responsible for user authentication and management.

docs.title: Deployment
docs.text: The deployment component is responsible for deploying the LTB backend and frontend components.

docs.title: Frontend
docs.text: The frontend allows users to access their labs and their devices.
